profile.name: Juan G.
profile.title: Front-end developer en Manfred
profile.description: I started as a Front-end developer in **2004**, back when **most of our job was fighting with Internet Explorer**… From that time until today, I’ve experienced firsthand:  - the birth of jQuery - the rise of SPAs - the emergence of CSS preprocessors - CSS-in-JS - new frameworks popping up every day  And here I am now, as motivated as ever. **Learning and improving every day**, because nobody knows everything in the tech world.  I carry a bag full of experiences of all kinds on my back. And I’ve met so many great people along the way, from whom I’ve learned a lot — not only in technical aspects but in many others as well.  If I had to highlight something about myself, it wouldn’t be my knowledge of front-end development, as every day I become more aware of everything I don’t know. However, I would highlight **my ability to learn everything I need to in order to do my job** with quality and efficiency.

challenges.description: I consider this to be the high point of my career: this is where I have been able to most faithfully transfer all the knowledge I have acquired throughout my career.  Despite being a small team (or maybe because of that), it is where I have been able to work together with my colleagues to create an environment of continuous improvement, of sharing knowledge, of delivery… All the "pieces" that I have been gathering over all these years are now in their place.

During my time at S-DOS as Front-end Lead, in addition to actively participating in the development of the projects we were involved in, I was in charge of the front-end team (6 people) making the architectural decisions necessary to drive the front-end work of the projects we worked on.  We developed a starter kit in Angular so that all future projects would be worked on in a standardized way, under the same common patterns, structures and conventions.  In addition, I was responsible for mentoring and helping the rest of the team, promoting training initiatives, pair-programming sessions, etc.

In this second stage, the company became a company with a digital signature product, so we went from working on many projects of various kinds to having a single product roadmap with only a few applications.  In this stage I also expanded my world (thanks to my colleagues supporting and guiding me) and began to _peck_ at things different from what I had done until now:  - I developed a couple of internal management applications for the product using Java/Vaadin - In my spare time I published a couple of native Android applications in the Play Store

Front-end lead developer.  - Converting from PSD/Fireworks designs to HTML/CSS code and then into the template system of choice (JSF, OpenCms, Drupal…) - Developing Javascript libraries and jQuery plugins for richer UI experience - Collaborating on development of internal framework for the team, defining UI and tools to make my team-mates happier - Developing cross-platform mobile apps with tools like PhoneGap or Appcelerator Titanium - Developing mobile apps using native SDKs
Maintenance and development of new features for a web platform focused on agricultural information. This was a stage of discoveries—where my journey as a front-end developer began.

details.name: Migraine monitor
details.description:
I’m currently developing an application to monitor migraine episodes. The idea is to collect data (intensity, symptoms, medication, etc.) about the episodes to later analyze it and generate charts.

The goal is also to use AI to identify patterns and determine potential triggers for the episodes.

details.name: inTEAmate
details.description:
Development of a native Android application (written in Java): a timer to brew the perfect cup of tea based on the variety you want to enjoy.

Unfortunately, I stopped maintaining it, and Google Play Store eventually deprecated and removed it a few months ago.

manfredSpecificData.desiredJobDescription:
I am motivated by working on the product. Focusing all my effort on moving an idea forward and seeing it become a reality little by little.

I really value working in a development team that is not too large, side by side, where you can learn from your colleague and everyone is pulling in the same direction. But on the other hand, I also love doing my bit by leading a somewhat larger team with less experienced people and giving them everything I have learned over the years.

I wouldn't like to have a rigid schedule, I need to balance my family life with my work life. I like people who treat each other with respect and who value responsibility more than a time-tracking tool.
manfredSpecificData.goodPractices:
I’m not a fan of buzzwords; for me, the best design pattern is common sense. And experience has shown me that, most of the time, this holds true.

I strive to be pragmatic while writing code with the mindset that someone (possibly myself) will need to revisit it later to modify or extend it. This is why I always try to make things as simple and explicit as possible.

To achieve this, I aim to follow the SOLID principles (without obsessing over them—pragmatism always comes first).

Specifically, I’m particularly focused on clearly separating responsibilities and decoupling anything that could cause issues in the future.
